title: company-wants-hire-100-people-borders-town
story: AN ENERGY supplier says it will hire  people in the Borders in the coming months.Peoplersquos Energy is taking over the former OVO Energy offices in Selkirks Ettrick Riverside building at Dunsdale Road.Peoplersquos Energy co-founder David Pike says the Borders has a "lot of talented people trained in the [energy] sector".Local MP John Lamont hailed the news as ldquovery welcome, nodding to the number of workers who have lost their jobs during the coronavirus pandemic.Mr Pike, , said the new roles will include ndash but not be limited to ndash call centre positions.He said: "We will obviously help the local economy and well be able to continue the tradition of energy sector work."We have customers who vote on local representatives to sit on advisory boards ndash we want to include people in our management."Peoples Energy is a community initiative business, for the people, by the people."In May, OVO Energy revealed that nearly  jobs would be lost at its Selkirk site.In response to the Peoples Energy announcement, Mr Lamont, of the Conservatives, said: "This is very welcome news that comes amid a spate of job losses in the Borders."I am delighted that Peoplersquos Energy are able to tap into the energy expertise in Selkirk left behind from previous employers in the town.ldquoIt would be a shamethis industry knowledge had been lost."This is a vote of confidence in the area and I hope that Peoplersquos Energy will have many successful years here."Peoplersquos Energy hopes to use the next  months to establish itself and build its workforce, but the company is also hoping to eventually grow further.Mr Pike said: "I see no reason not to expand ndash weve got the space."Were growing rapidly. This last month weve grown by , customers ndash , overall."We also want to address fuel poverty."We want our prepaid tarf to be as close to our direct debit tarf as people with prepaid tarfs are potentially more likely to be in fuel poverty."South of Scotland Enterprise chairman Russel Griggs was present at Peoplersquos Energyrsquos launch at Ettrick Riverside.Professor Griggs said: ldquoPeoplersquos Energyrsquos expansion into Selkirk and the potential of new jobs is fantastic news for the community.ldquoThe Borders has a fantastic reputation for high quality customer service and expertise in the energy sector and I see this as a much-needed boost for Selkirk, and the wider south of Scotland economy.Christine Grahame MSP ndash who represents Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale ndash said she ldquoheartily welcomes the plans.She said: ldquoThe creation of  jobs would be good news at any time but even more so now during the pandemic and accompanying economic crisis.The company also plans to reward customers through its profit share scheme, which aims to give customers back  per cent of profits as a rebate ndash either a bill reduction or account credit.However, as a new company, Peoplersquos Energy requires stability before making good on this, according to Mr Pike.

title: results-day-borders-school-pupils-praised-hard-work
story: SCHOOL pupils have been praised by Scottish Borders Councilas they received their qualication results todayfollowing an unusual academic year.The coronavirus lockdown meant exams were cancelled, so grades were based on estimates made by teachers.SBC leader Shona Haslam hailed pupils for having ldquorisen to the challenge set by the lockdown.Mrs Haslam said: "This yearrsquos students have been faced with an unprecedented situation and they are to be commended for the remarkable flexibility and resilience that they have shown in the circumstances."Around , exams were sat in the Borders this academic year, with , at Higher,  at Advanced Higher and , at National .This year, S students sitting exams at National  SCQF Level , with grades ranging from A to C, achieved a pass rate of . per cent. And overall, attainment at SCQF Levels - increased.Borders schools also remain in the top quartile nationally for positive destinations, with . per cent of students achieving a "positive and sustained destination".Mrs Haslam extended her praise and thanks to members of Borders teaching staff.She said: "Teaching staff have worked extremely hard together with the SQA to make sure that the assessment process has been as fair and transparent as possible and there has been minimal impact on our young people and what they have been able to achieve."As a result of that determination, it is encouraging to see that Scottish Borders has attained a set of results which demonstrate a picture of consistent achievement."In S exams sat in May this year in core subjects such as Literacy and Numeracy,  per cent of students achieved a literacy award, with  per cent achieving a National  English award.In numeracy,  per cent of S students received a numeracy award, with . per cent awarded a National  in maths.Mrs Haslam added: "Exam results day is one of the most momentous events in a young personrsquos le at the best of times.ldquoThis yearrsquos students have been faced with an unprecedented situation and they are to be commended for the remarkable flexibility and resilience that they have shown in the circumstances.ldquoIt is encouraging to see that our commitment to preparing our young people for their next steps in le continues to pay idends, with an increasing number of them being able to leave education with higher levels of qualications and attainment and move on to positive and sustained destinations.ldquoWhatever their situation, Irsquod like to commend the young people of the Scottish Borders on their results and hard work, and thank their teachers, parents and carers for all their support which has been especially important over these past few months.ldquoI certainly hope that as many as possible of our young people received the results they were hoping for.ldquoHowever, for any who didnrsquot, the first thing to remember is donrsquot panic.ldquoThere is no wrong pathway for our young people everyonersquos learner journey is dferent and their school or an organisation like Skills Development Scotland have staff on hand to provide all the reassurance and advice they need.Support for pupils can be found hereor by calling the Skills Development Scotlandhelpline on   .The helpline is open from am-pm on August  and then from .am-pm on August -.SDS helpline staff can also offer guidance on UCAS and college applications as well as title: author-sebastian-barry-says-borders-magical-allure
story: Sebastian Barry, the current Laureate for Irish Fiction, is sad to miss Melrose and the ldquomagical allure of the Borders this year.The Costa-winning author of Days Without Endand A Long, Long Way, booked to appear at this yearrsquos Borders Book Festival, has visited Melrose three times, and the area clearly made an indelible mark on him.He said: ldquoIf yoursquore going to be spoiled in this lehellip twice I went [to Melrose] and for mysterious reasons they gave me the Walter Scott Prize [for Historical Fiction] each time."And then another time I was thrilled to go to give the prize to Benjamin Myers.ldquoAll three times not only did I slowly gather a friendship with [festival director] Alistair [Moffat], who was really a great guy, but we were so spoiled, I donrsquot knowwe were fit for human le after that."We had to come back to normal places after that.He continued: ldquoThe Borders held a magical allure for me. You donrsquot just want to go there ndash you need to get back to it.ldquoWhen Irsquom  and trying to think of the signal things that have happened to me as an old critter writer going around, thatrsquoll be high up on the list. Just the welcome of it.Though Barry wonrsquot be able to meet his readers in person this year, he will be talking to an online audience on August  about his latest book, A Thousand Moons.Sequel to rsquos Days Without End, A Thousand Moonsis set in  Tennessee and narrated by native American Winona, who tells of her unorthodox upbringing by two men and her quest for revenge after she endures a brutal attack.Barry spoke to the Border from his home in County Wicklow, on a beautul morning that he predicted with nonchalance would not last.ldquoJust for two hours itrsquos summer ndash itrsquos really beautul, about  degrees, wersquove just had coffee outside, just to feel it.ldquoAnd then it will give way to rain for the rest of eternity, sohellip But in this moment, itrsquos good.Unable to travel to promote A Thousand Moonsor visit the ious book festivals that would normally be on his itinerary, Barry has spent much time in the mountains that look down on his home.He has also been reading books such as Meditationsby Marcus Aurelius ndash works that are ldquostrong winds to stir away the fog of the pandemic.He is sanguine about the impact of lockdown on his book festival plans.ldquoIrsquom a slightly introverted person so doing the festivals does require an effort of mind for me, he said, ldquobut nevertheless now I donrsquot have them, I realise even more how unusual they are.ldquoEspecially for godless folk like myself, itrsquos a kind of reaffirmation of humankind, because you do your reading and yoursquore there talking to your fellow writers, especially at the Borders Book Festival because they have it arranged like that.,params: .pushldquoItrsquos very important for the participants to be among each other as well.He added: ldquoThe aftermath of it is that you have your signing queue. Andyoursquore very old like me ndashyoursquore  ndash you might have some people in the signing queue and thatrsquos a really lovely thing because each person comes up and says oftentimes quite private things to you.ldquoEveryone is on their best behaviour. Yoursquore on your best behaviour! And therersquos just a sort of clemency about it."Therersquos some very deep magic in it and I miss that.But Barry is positive about the book festivalrsquos online efforts to bring its ldquomagic to readers.ldquoDoing it online reaffirms the importance of people gathering to talk about books, to meet the people who make books, to meet the people who read books, he said.ldquoAt a certain level it doesnrsquot sound a lot but actually it turns out to be a huge thing that wersquore now going to have to miss, and itrsquos wonderful the effort thatrsquos being made to perpetuate it.ldquoThis is going to be our effort to sort of be there, like a sympathetic magic, like a group of admirable witches brewing up something that feels like the real thing.To see Sebastian Barry in conversation with Mairi Kidd, Creative Scotlandrsquos Head of Literature, Languages and Publishing, you can click this link.The festival is sponsored by investment management company Baillie Gford.

title: government-says-cannot-order-schools-stay-open-local-lockdowns
story: The Government cannot ldquodecree that keeping schools open must be prioritised over pubs during local lockdowns to combat spikes in coronavirus cases, the schools minister has said.Nick Gibb insisted on Wednesday that all children willto school in England in September but said the decisions to enforce closures to prevent new outbreaks will be made locally.Experts have made it increasingly clear that some restrictions will need toin order to fulfil the Governmentrsquos commitment on schools while preventing the rapid spread of Covid- from resuming.Our briefing:https:t.co XynnKASmdash Childrens Commissioner for EnglandAugust , Childrenrsquos Commissioner for England Anne Longfield has said the reopening of schools ldquoshould be prioritised, insisting they must be first to reopen and last to close during any local lockdowns.Asked about her comments, Mr Gibb told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme: ldquoItrsquos a more nuanced response. It does have to depend on the facts of the case and thatrsquos why the local director of public health will be responsible for the response to that spike.Pressed on whether schools should be the last to close, he said: ldquoWhat Irsquom saying is that all children will be ing to school in September, including in those areas that are currently subject to a local lockdown ndash Manchester, Greater Manchester, Leicester and so on ndash because it is important children are back in school.ldquoBut you canrsquot decree this for every single case and it will depend on the circumstances of a local increase in the infection rate, and that is why it is being led by the director of public health in localities. But we want all children back in school.Professor Neil Ferguson, whose modelling led to the decision to impose the lockdown, suggested ministers would need to ldquorow back on the relaxation of restrictions, such as in social and leisure venues and with increased working from home, to allow a full-timeto schools.colleges, link lots of households together, reconnect the social network which social distancing measures have deliberately disconnected" data-source"Professor Neil Ferguson"He told Today: ldquoI mean that really is a policy decision, but Irsquom just saying, in my view, it is likely that some form of those measures will be necessary to maintain control of transmission.Prof Ferguson, whose advice continues to inform the Governmentrsquos response despite his resignation from the Sage advisory group, said there is some evidence that older teenagers transmit the virus just as effectively as adults.ldquoThe risk then is that big schools, comprehensives, universities, FEcolleges, link lots of households together, reconnect the social network which social distancing measures have deliberately disconnected. And that poses a real risk of amplication of transmission, of case numbers going up quite sharply, he said.Ms Longfield had earlier accused the Government of treating children ldquoas an afterthought during the Covid- crisis.In a briefing paper, she said keeping schools open should be the ldquoabsolute priority, adding: ldquoEducation should be prioritised over other sectors: first to open, last to close.ldquoWhen only a limited amount of social interaction is feasible, the amount accounted for by education must be protected ndash at the expense of other sectors activities.Labour was unequivocal in backing Ms Longfieldrsquos demand, with leader Sir Keir Starmer warning Mr Johnson he has only a month to fix the test and trace programme to prevent a resurgence in outbreaks.vw,vw,px, px"ldquoWe were promised a world-beating system, we havenrsquot got it. So wersquore saying to the Government very clearly today, time is running out, Sir Keir said during a visit to Stoke.ldquoSchools must be the priority and we certainly support the call that schools should be the last to close.In Scotland, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon appeared to take action to prioritise schools when she ordered bars, cafes and restaurants to close in Aberdeen as an outbreak of  new cases prompted ato lockdown restrictions.ldquoActing now, we judge, gives us the time and the space to protect the ability of our young people toto education, she said.Meanwhile, an influential cross-party committee of MPs blamed the Governmentrsquos earlier failure to quarantine travellers arriving in the UK for having ldquoaccelerated the spread of Covid-.The report by the Commons Home Affairs Committee was scathing of the ldquoinexplicable decision to lt all border restrictions in March, which they say led to ldquomany more people contracting Covid-.Figures published by the UKrsquos statistics agencies show there have now been , deaths registered in the UK where Covid- was mentioned on the death certicate..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Government says it cannot order schools to stay open during local lockdowns

title: john-hume-made-peace-visible-darkest-moments
story: John Hume made peace visible for others even in the darkest moments, his funeral has been told.Mourners heard that the former SDLP leader and Nobel laureate saved the lives of others through his vision and work.During his funeral at St Eugenersquos Cathedral in Londonderry, Mr Hume was described as a man who made his family ldquolaugh, dream and think.vw,vw,px, px"SDLP leader Colum Eastwood and Taoiseach Micheal Martin arrive at St Eugenersquos Cathedral Father Paul Farren said that Mr Hume gave his le for his country.He said: ldquoHe focused on unity and peace, and giving that dignity to every person.ldquoWe should never underestimate how dficult it was for John to cross the road and do what was intensely unpopular for the greater good.ldquoEven in the darkest moments, when people would have been forgiven for having no hope, John made peace visible for others.ldquoHis vision revealed what could be, and with time and determination and single-mindedness and stubbornness, he convinced others that peace could be a reality.vw,vw,px, px"John Hume Junior speaks at his fatherrsquos funeral In his homily he said that Mr Hume never lost faith in peace, nor faith in his ability to convince others that peace was the only way.ldquoIf ever you want to see a man who gave his le for his country, and his health, that man is John Hume. The world knows it, he added.Father Farren said that John and his we Pat have secured their place in the history of Ireland, ldquoJohn being Irelandrsquos greatest.Mr Humersquos son John Hume Junior told those gathered in the Cathedral that his dadwas a Derryman to his core.Mr Hume added: ldquoIf dad were here today, in the fullness of his health, witnessing the current tensions in the world, he wouldnrsquot waste the opportunity to say a few words.Thanks to everyone who has lit a candle for peace this evening in memory of John. #JohnsLightpic chiylbnPGSmdash Social Democratic and Labour PartyAugust , ldquoHersquod talk about our common humanity, the need to respect ersity and dference, to protect and deepen democracy, to value education, and to place non-violence at the absolute centre.ldquoHe might also stress the right to a living wage and a roof over your head, to decent healthcare and education.ldquoMarrying Pat, our mother, was without a doubt dadrsquos greatest achievement and she enabled him to reach his full potential.ldquoAlong with mum, he taught us all our values and gave us all our moral compass. And for that we will be forever in their debt.Messages were also read from former US president Bill Clinton, Prime Minister Boris Johnson and U singer Bono.vw,vw,px, px"Northern Irelandrsquos First Minister Arlene Foster Among the dignitaries were Irelandrsquos President Michael D Higgins, Taoiseach Micheal Martin, Northern Irelandrsquos First Minister Arlene Foster and Deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill.Others included former SDLP leader Mark Durkan and current leader Colum Eastwood.Mr Durkan and Mr Humersquos eldest daughter Therese led the readings while singer Anne Marie Hickey was joined by organist Aidan Watkins and Frank Gallagher, who played the violin.Prayers of the faithful were read by Mr Humersquos grandchildren Dee, Aoibhe, Rachel and Una.A poem written by Aidan Hume, Mr Humersquos son, was read by Mo Hume.vw,vw,px, px"Frank Gallagher plays the violin during the service Aidan, who is based in Boston, was not able to attend the funeral because of Covid- travel restrictions.Mo became tearful as she read her siblingrsquos tribute to her father.ldquoYou made us realise a border is just a line on a map. Itrsquos in our hearts and minds where we need to bridge the gap, she said.ldquoThorough over  years of violence, hurt and unrelenting stress, those underlying conditions you never stopped trying to address.ldquoI donrsquot think I ever said aloud how you made us all so incredibly proud. All you ever wanted was to make the world a better place.vw,vw,px, px"John Hume died on Monday Pope Francis also paid tribute to Mr Hume.A statement from the Vatican said: ldquoHis Holiness Pope Francis was saddened to learn of the death of John Hume, and sends the assurance of his prayers to his family and to all who mourn his loss.ldquoMindful of the Christian faith that inspired John Humersquos untiring efforts to promote dialogue, reconciliation and peace among the people of Northern Ireland, his Holiness commends his noble soul to the loving mercy of Almighty God.A message from the Dalai Lama was also read during the service.ldquoI was pleased to be able to meet John during one of my several visits to Northern Ireland, he said.vw,vw,px, px"President Michael D Higgins arrives for the funeral ldquoIndeed, his deep conviction in the power of dialogue and negotiations in resolving the problem in his homeland has been an example of non-violent resolution of issues.ldquoIt was his leadership and his faith in the power ofnegotiations that enabled the  Good Friday Agreement to be reached. His steady persistence set an example for all of us to follow.ldquoAlthough my fellow Nobel laureate is no longer with us, his message about peace and non-violence in the resolution of conflict, no matter how protracted or dficult it may seem to be, will long survive him. He lived a truly meaningful le.Derry musician Phil Coulter played Mr Humersquos favourite song The Town I Loved So Well on the piano at the end of the service.Speaking before the funeral, Mr Eastwood said they were grateful to have had Mr Hume.vw,vw,px, px"Father Paul Farren ldquoThere is work to be done and John was always forward thinking. He gave us the , he gave us the pathway, he gave us the opportunity to do this free from violence, he said.ldquoWe have to keep going to build the shared island that we want.Mrs Foster described it as a ldquosad day.ldquoI was reflecting that this has been a very dficult year for the SDLP with the loss of John Dallat and Seamus Mallon. We are here to support colleagues and indeed the family.Ms OrsquoNeill said that Mr Humersquos death marks the start of the end of an era.ldquoThe era of Martin McGuinness, John Hume, Ian Paisley ndash all dferent political perspectives, she added.ldquoBut as we lose big giants like that there is a huge onus on us, as the post-Good Friday Agreement generation of political leaders, to be able to carry out the good work they started.People lined the streets outside the Cathedral and applauded as the funeral procession made its way along the route to the city cemetery where a private burial took place.Following a request from John Humes family, President Higgins and Sabina this evening lit a "candle for peace" at Aacuteras an Uachtaraacutein. pic GPZhkfRkpmdash President of IrelandAugust , Mrs Hume and her family acknowledged the crowds through the open car windows.The Derry politician, feted around the world as a peacemaker, died on Monday at the age of  after a long battle with dementia.In ordinary circumstances, Mr Humersquos funeral would have been expected to draw huge crowds, but numbers were limited due to coronavirus restrictions.Mr Hume was a key architect of the Good Friday Agreement and was awarded the Nobel peace prize for the pivotal role he played in ending the regionrsquos sectarian conflict.The former MP, Stormont Assembly member and MEP, led the party he helped found for  years.vw,vw,px, px"Northern Irelandrsquos Deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill arrives at St Eugenersquos Cathedral He was a prominent figure in the civil rights campaigns of the late s and also played a leading role in the formation of the credit union movement.Throughout his political career, he remained steadfast in his commitment to non-violence.His participation in secret talks with then Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams in the late s and early s was a key catalyst for the nascent peace process.The SDLP leader faced intense criticism, including some from within his own party, when his dialogue with Mr Adams became public in .Despite threats to his le, he persisted with his efforts to engage with the republican movement and to convince the IRA to end its campaign of violence.vw,vw,px, px"Pat Hume is embraced by family members as Mr Hume is taken into St Eugenersquos Cathedral The highlight of Mr Humersquos career came in  with the signing of the historic Good Friday accord which largely ended Northern Irelandrsquos -year sectarian conflict.Along with Ulster Unionist Party leader David Trimble, now Lord Trimble, Mr Hume was awarded the Nobel peace prize for his contribution to stopping the bloodshed.In , Mr Hume was named ldquoIrelandrsquos Greatest in a poll by Irelandrsquos national broadcaster RTE.His death came just six months after that of fellow Good Friday architect and long-time SDLP deputy leader Seamus Mallon.A number of vehicles were hijacked in Derry on Tuesday afternoon, with Mr Eastwood accusing those responsible of violating the grief of the city..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: John Hume  umade peace visible during darkest moments u

title: a-glowing-red-cloud-british-citizens-lebanon-describe-beirut-explosion
story: British citizens living in Lebanon have described the huge explosion in its capital city, with one describing seeing aldquoglowing red cloud and plume of smoke.Claire Malleson, from Dorset, has been working for the American University of Beirut in the city for two years and was jogging around campus at the time of the blast.It is not yet known how many British nationals are among those caught up in the aftermath, which has killed at least  people and injured more than , others.Ms Malleson told the PA news agency: ldquoI just felt this enormous explosion mdash I thought it was somewhere on campus because it felt a lot closer than the three miles away.ldquoI could see damage to the buildings near me and a glowing red cloud and a plume of smoke.ldquoI couldnrsquot really move, I was rooted to the spot.ldquoMy first thought was to go to a phone and call my parents, in case they saw a newsflash. I found my way back to one of the campus apartments.ldquoEveryone was walking in a daze. As soon as I got near the campus housing buildings, I could see there was panic. Everyone was saying they felt earthquake-like shakings and buildings had been shaking before the explosion.Ms Malleson, , said she normally runs closer to the seaport but had changed her routine because of lockdown restrictions. She ed to her flat, which was undamaged, although she said the buildings in the area all had shattered windows.She said: ldquoToday it is quiet. All my friends are OK, some friends of friends were injured by glass.vw,vw,px, px"It is unclear how many British nationals have been caught up in the blast ldquoWe were warned about possible toxic fumes but the university air monitorsshow no problems, but really all we can do is stay in. As soon as there are official ways to help, wersquoll do all we can. The blood banks are all calling for urgent donations.She said people speculating about the cause of the explosion was ldquodangerous.ldquoI think that what bothers me the most is people outside Lebanon weighing in and deciding it was an act of aggression or an attack, she said.ldquoIt feels like that could ignite tensions that we really donrsquot want here. It takes away from the fact that on the ground here in Beirut the destruction is so catastrophic that people just need to find a way to get through the day, and the weeks to come.ldquoWe already had minimal power supplies and people were already struggling to survive with the financial crisis.ldquoSpeculation is so dangerous in this region.Richard Gordon-Smith, from Twickenham, said he felt the shockwaves of the blast more than  miles away, describing it as like ldquobeing slapped in the face.The -year-old language teacher and counsellor lives in the coastal town of Damour and was working outside at the time of the explosion.He told PA: ldquoSuddenly I simultaneously heard a very loud noise and felt something hitting me, almost like a slap in the face, a strike in my ear and my eardrums reverberated painfully.ldquoIt was not just a loud bang like a motorcycle might make, it was something much greater. I looked around and saw other neighbours coming out onto their balconies.ldquoI thought it was the next neighbourhood along, I didnrsquot think a shockwave could have come all the way from Beirut.vw,vw,px, px"A man inspects his a damaged car after a massive explosion in Beirut He said the incident had come at the ldquoworst possible time for the city, which is suffering from a financial crisis, as well as dealing with the coronavirus health crisis.Mr Gordon-Smith said: ldquoAll of the hospitals have been wrecked. Patients are out on the street instead of being treated inside hospitals.ldquoThis could exacerbate things beyond the tipping point.ldquoTalking to some of my friends who are Syrian refugees, and they have gone into a state of complete shock because it brought back many flashbacks, especially for the children who are screaming, and crying and canrsquot sleep..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title:  uA glowing red cloud u: British citizens in Lebanon describe Beirut explosion

title: schools-reopening-20-public-buses-taken-pupils
story: PAYING passengers will be banned from  bus services in the Borders as schools .Scottish Borders Councilhas announced that  routes are being deregistered from public use from August , so more room will be available for pupils.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoIt is important to emphasise that while many of the services being closed off to the public may have theoretically been open for public use, the uptake has historically been extremely low, and in some cases unused entirely.To see the full list of routes being taken over for school children only, readers can visit the councilrsquos website.When pupilsto classrooms on Tuesday, five months after the coronavirus pandemic prompted the closure of schools, they will not have to obey social-distancing or wear face coverings. The same will apply to students using school transport.However, pupils will have to use hand sanitiser when they board buses, and the vehicles will be cleaned thoroughly.While unveiling these measures, the council also announced that  public bus services will be taken over for school-use only. The council says the move is designed to ldquomaximise capacity for pupils.Affected routes include the Borders Buses service P from Borders Busesand the Telfords service S .Ms Logan said: "In all instances,any member of the public who would normally use the services still needs to travel and there is no alternative public transport, the council will provide assistance."Anyone in this situation should contact our Passenger Transport team on PLACEtransport@scotborders.gov.uk or call   ."Throughout the rest of this week we will be providing regular updates and information for parents, carers and pupils on all aspects of theto school, all of which can be accessed online at www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolreopening"On buses which will contain both pupils and paying customers, the pupils will be given a dedicated section of the bus. Everyone will have to obey social distancing and wear masks.Services which require pupils to follow government COVID- guidelines include Borders Buses XBorders Buses and Telfords H .

title: east-lothians-football-teams-back-september
story: The countyrsquos six senior football teams have been left on the sidelines since March, when the coronavirus pandemic brought the season to a premature close.Now, early discussions have identied a possible start for the new campaign.The Lowland East South West Pyramid group ndash representing teams from the Scottish Lowland Football League, the East of Scotland Football League, the South of Scotland Football League and the West of Scotland Football League ndash held its first Zoom call earlier this month.Clubs are hoping to restart training in the coming weeks, with a view to playing again at the end of September or beginning of October.Managers from East Lothianrsquos teams cautiously welcomed the announcement and hoped it was the start of light at the end of the tunnel.Geoff Jones, manager of Dunbar United, said: ldquoI think, to be honest, it is an enormous boost.ldquoNot just from a football perspective but just a mental health perspective as well ndash for a lot of people to get back to doing some level of group interaction.ldquoWe have pushed ndash as have a lot of clubs ndash inidual training programmes through virtual apps, like Strava, but some people are highly motivated and others find it dficult outwith a group environment.Meanwhile, Johnny Harvey was looking forward to starting his first full season in charge of Tranent Juniors, having been appointed in February.The Foresters Park side will be looking to build on a promising campaign, which saw them sitting fourth in the East of Scotland Football League Premier Division when the season was stopped.Harvey said: ldquoTo get some kind of normality back in everybodyrsquos lives would be a huge boost.ldquoSupporters, players, myself ndash everybody is exactly the same and is excited to get back on the field as soon as possible.Kevin McDonald, manager at Musselburgh Athletic, was frustrated to see football halted in the spring with his side on an impressive run of form, including securing a place in this seasonrsquos Scottish Cup after a - thumping of Mid Annandale in the South and East Shield.Now, he is hoping to see that continue when the upcoming campaign gets under way.He said: ldquoI have been pestering the secretary at Musselburgh to find outhe has any information.ldquoWe are all desperate to get back ndash myself and the players are the same.ldquoWe will be looking at a seven-month break by the time we restart games.ldquoThe sooner we are allowed to get back training and playing friendlies the better.ldquoI think we will need more friendlies with not playing for so long as well.Joe Hamill, player-manager at Haddington Athletic, said everyone at the club was keen to see the season get back under way.He stressed that training could look slightly dferent than it did previously, with stringent cleaning measures being put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.He said: ldquoItrsquos a wee bit of light at the end of the tunnel for us. Irsquove been getting messages from the players asking lsquowhen are we starting back rsquoldquoIrsquom in the same boat and just want to get on with it.

title: pop-up-cycle-lane-coastal-road
story: While mph speed limits are being introduced in Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton.As part of the Spaces for People initiative to provide additional space for physical distancing to protect public health, work has started on a temporary cycle route between Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton which will run parallel to the main B Edinburgh Road.The three-metre wide path will be created by laying hard surfacing down on the grass verge on the north side of the carriageway between the two communities.The path will run alongside the footpath between the boatyard access at Prestonpans to just past the old power station with a white line separating the cyclepath and walkway.This is the councilrsquos latest project to improvesocial distancing in the wake of the Covid- crisis.The local authority received pound.million from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People fund to introduce ious countywide measures to make it easier to social distance in town centres and improve cycle and pedestrian paths.As well as the roadside cycle route, the speed limit on Edinburgh Road, which is normally mph, will be reduced to mph and speed limits in the twocommunities reduced to just mph.The plan for the cycle path has seen dozens of painted stones created by local schoolchildren, which line the footpath, move across to the other side of the road.The stones are a symbol of hope and unity during the Covid- crisis, and many similar displays have been created throughout East Lothian and the whole country.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoWe received many comments in the public consultation around Spaces for People on the need to provide suitable space for people cycling.ldquoMany people are currently cycling this route and we need to cater for the current increase in cyclists during the pandemic period.ldquoIn common with other Spaces for People measures, this route is for temporary use as we gradually move out of restrictions and will also provide a viable alternative to the use of the private car and or public transport for shorter-distanced essential or leisure trips in the area.The works also include the introduction of temporary crossings of Edinburgh Road at either end of the route through the use of lsquobuildoutsrsquo and bolt-down bollards.In addition, the proposals also include traffic calming measures on Edinburgh Road to slow down traffic with a temporary reduction in the speed limit to mph between the two communities, in tandem with the introduction of mph limits within the communities themselves.MrHampshire added: ldquoWe were aware of a collection of painted stones that have been carefully laid by local schoolchildren alongside the existing footway along Edinburgh Road and recognise that these are important to the local community.ldquoThe community council arranged for these to be carefully collected prior to the start of the works and they have been relocated on the other side of the road.

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: beach-boardwalk-look-blooming-great-thanks-volunteers
story: The team has been working hard over the last fortnight to create plant beds along one side of the walkway as it carries out landscaping work on the site.The boardwalk was created two years ago across the road from the holiday village to provide easy access to the beach for wheelchair users and, thanks to grants from the Walk With Scott Foundation and Beach Wheelchairs charity, two beach wheelchairs are available to borrow from Seton Sands.Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom said that the boardwalk, which also has three picnic tables and seats, had become a popular place for locals and holidaymakers all year round and members were delighted to be able to start work on its surroundings.A spokesperson said: ldquoIt was always our intention to landscape the area around the boardwalk and we are delighted that this work has finally got under way.ldquoOver the last two weeks, members of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, assisted by several enthusiastic and hard-working volunteers, have transformed one side of the boardwalk.ldquoA long raised bed has been sited alongside the pavement.ldquoA rockery has been created at the beginning of the boardwalk.ldquoSoil was provided by East Lothian Council and the areas planted up with plants suitable for the exposed situation near the sea, which will, in time, provide colour and interest for most of the summer.ldquoIn due course, we hope to make similar improvements to the other side of the boardwalk.

title: luxury-hampers-given-students-covid-19-efforts
story: A total of pound, has been allocated by Santander Universities to provide gts to , students at QMU and Edinburgh Napier University who supported the NHS in the fight against the virus.QMU has offered its nursing and allied health professionsrsquo students on the frontline a choice of one of two luxury food hampers ndash a lsquopamper hamperrsquo or breakfast hamper.The gts have been provided by Artisan Larder Scotland, founded by QMU graduate David McVey.Edinburgh Napier University has linked up with East Lothian-based sushi company Minato Sushi to offer its own eligible School of Health and Social Care students a pound voucher for the business as a thank you for their efforts as part of the countryrsquos Covid- response.Sir Paul Grice, principal and vice-chancellor of Queen Margaret University, said: ldquoWe are incredibly proud of all of our students from the School of Health Sciences, especially those who are playing their part in the NHSrsquos fight against Covid-.ldquoThanks to the continuing generosity and support of Santander Universities, we have been able to not only provide this thank you gt for hundreds of our hard-working health students but also support one of our graduate businesses in the process."I hope the students enjoy the gt ndash they are doing fantastic work.

title: tesco-seeks-drop-cash-obligation
story: The company says it no longer owns land ndash the site of its former store at Mall Avenue ndash which is to be turned into  flats by a developer.Tesco has applied to East Lothian Council to mody a contract which was part of an earlier planning consent for residential development at the town centre site, dating back to .The sum of pound, had to be given for extra accommodation at Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School.Pritchett Planning Consultancy, on behalf of Tesco Stores Limited, said Tesco now owned and operated the supermarket and petrol filling station at Olivebank Road.It stated: ldquoTesco was previously involved in a land transaction which enabled residential development to be constructed on the site of the former Tesco store site. This transaction took place over a decade ago and the land of the residential development site is not owned by Tesco.ldquoThe section  agreement states that Tesco Stores Limited shall pay an education contribution relating to a residential development on land identied as the third subjects.ldquoTesco has no ownership of the subject site and is not involved in any way in developing the land for residential purposes.The document added: ldquoThis proposed modication to the section  agreement by Tesco seeks to remove Tescorsquos name from the agreement and to replace this with the lsquothird proprietorsrsquo as owners of the residential land on the third subject site.ldquoIn making this change, the agreement would be more aligned with government policy on legal obligations as the agreement would bind the landowner to which the agreement relates rather than a third party which has no involvement in the land or its development.

title: covid-19-testing-centre-returns-former-power-station-site
story: It re-started todayand runs until Wednesday at the site on Edinburgh Road, am-pm.Tests can be booked through the UK Governmentrsquos online system, www.gov.uk get-coronavirus-test, for those who are key workers or those who live with one.Alternatively they can be booked through the NHS website at www.nhs.uk conditions coronavirus-covid-A limited number of home testing kits are available for those who cannot make it to the testing site, but priority will continue to be given to key workers and can be secured by booking through their employer.As of May , testing is for people who have symptoms and are over the age of five as well as household members who are experiencing symptoms.Symptoms include a new continuous cough, a fever and a loss or change in smell or taste.Anyone who develops symptoms is asked to self-isolate immediately as well as all members of their household until they receive a negative test result.More information on testing is available at www.gov.scot publications coronavirus-covid--getting-testedThis is not the first time Covid- testing has taken place at the former power station site.A mobile testing unit first visited the site between May  and  and later visited again from May -June .It was operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve units in Scotland.

title: seabird-centre-delighted-open
story: The centre, an independent charity based in North Berwick, reopened last Thursday for the first time in four months after it closed its doors in March due to the coronavirus pandemic.Several new systems were put in place but people were said to have been accommodating and supportive.Due to its long period of closure and these new systems, the centre was open from Thursday until Sunday last week and then closed Monday to Wednesday.This allowed staff, all of whom had been on furlough, the time to adjust to the new ways of working and enhanced safety measures, as well as the chance to review the experience to seeany improvements were needed.The opening is said to have gone well and without any major issues.A spokesperson said: ldquoWersquove all needed to adapt very quickly but are happy to say that members and visitors have been hugely understanding and supportive of the changes.ldquoWe will open again daily from Thursday and canrsquot wait!The bookable timed visits to its newly refurbished Discovery Experience were fully booked all weekend, as were the wildle boat trips.The next step is to bring back the outdoor learning programme, with plans to celebrate National Marine Weekthrough bookable outdoor activities.

title: shop-owner-thankful-invaluable-support-pandemic
story: Sharon Brown, of Blueberry gt shop, praised the local authorityrsquos prompt response, adding: ldquoThe council was very good to get the money out so quickly.She said: ldquoAs a single person, my only wage comes from the shop so, when it is closed, I have no income but still have to pay bills such as rent and water and sewerage charges.ldquoThe grant from the council allowed me to keep my head above water ndash without it I donrsquot know what I would have done.She stressed that she was glad that her High Street shop was allowed to reopen when it did, as the lockdown was taking its toll on finances and a ldquoworrying time lay ahead.She kept her business going during that time by launching an online shop and making free local deliveries in the EH postcode area to ensure her valued customers still got gts and cards to mark special occasions.Since reopening, Sharon, who also lives in Musselburgh and is secretary of Musselburgh Business Partnership, has been encouraged by the support from the community.She said: ldquoLots of people were glad to see the shop back and I have had lots of positive comments about it.She urged shoppers to continue to support small, independent shops in a bid to keep town centres thriving, with the message ldquouse it or lose it.ldquoIt is important to recognise that small businesses also kept people provided with necessities during the lockdown and stepped into the breach. It proved more than ever how important local, independent businesses are to the area, she added.

title: flag-heritage-centre-athelstaneford-reopen
story: The interpretative centre, housed in a converted th-century doocot to the rear of the villagersquos parish church, was unable to open for the visitor season at the start of April due to the coronavirus pandemic.It is the first time in more than  years that the four-star visitor attraction, telling the story of the Saltire, has had to remain closed.The centre trustees said that health and safety precautions were being put in place to protect visitors.Details regarding physical distancing and the number of people who are allowed to enter the building will be displayed at the centre.Trust chair David Williamson said: ldquoThe trust has had a number of enquiries as to when the centre would be reopening, and there is obviously public interest in being able to come to this historic site.ldquoVisitors particularly enjoy the audio-visual dramatisation of the ninth-century battle in which a white saltire, the cross of the patron saint, against a blue sky led to the adoption of Scotlandrsquos national flag.The centre will be open from am until pm every day until the end of October.Admission is free.

title: siblings-vow-complete-dads-munro-bagging-dream
story: David Choat, often along with we Judy, both , had scaled more than  of Scotlandrsquos highest peaks before he was diagnosed with the condition in November .Now, his children Paul, Matt, Becky and Adam are getting ready to tick off the remaining  mountains, which total , metres.Paul, who lives in Macmerry with we Becca and nine-month-old daughter Skye, said: ldquoAs soon as it became apparent that dad would not be able to finish them off, it was something we came up with, despite not knowing how much they still had to do.ldquoWe started tossing round the idea at Christmas time and we really proposed the idea then.ldquoBy that point, I had spoken to my siblings and they were on board.ldquoWe sat down with mum and dad and proposed the idea.ldquoBoth were really keen on the whole thing.ldquoIt was an idea for us to get mum up the hills as well.ldquoWithout dad, she has been missing out on it a bit and, from dadrsquos point of view, to get to the end of the list would mean a fair amount, evenhe cannot do it himself.From there came the idea of raising funds for My Namersquo Doddie Foundation, formed by former Scotland rugby internationalist Doddie Weir, who himself has MND.Paul, , described it as a ldquono brainer to raise funds for the good cause, which aims to find a cure for the condition or improve treatment.Fteen Munros remained to be ticked off until the weekend before last, when Paul was joined by older brother Adam ndash who lives in Haddington with we Samantha and sons Leon and Lochlan ndash in scaling the ,-metre An Stuc, near Killin.Paul said: ldquoIt was not too bad. We were a bit sore the next day but not too bad.Matt, who lives in London, and Becky, of Livingston, were unable to climb the first Munro with them but have committed to tackling the remaining .Seven more could be achieved by the end of next month, with Arsquo Chralaig , Tom a Choinich , Mullach Fraoch-choire , Carn nan Gobhar, Ciste Dhubh , Sgurr na Banachdichand Bla Bheinnall pencilled in.That would just leave Creise , Sgor na h-Ulaidh , Beinn Fhionnlaidh , Beinn Sgulaird , Stob Coire an Laoigh , Meall arsquo Bhuiridhand Sgurr Morto be ticked off in .Paul said his dad, who lives with his we in Aberdeen, had wanted to complete the  Munros after finding out he was closing in on the total.He said: ldquoMy dad was unbelievably healthy and fit. They would be out walking and most of their holidays revolved around walking tours.ldquoJust generally, they were very active and very healthy so the diagnosis was a bit of a bolt out of the blue.ldquoIt was devastating my dad had retired the year before and my mum and dad had big plans for retirement, all of which have pretty much fallen through.Paul told the Courier his dad remained upbeat and ldquounbelievably positive despite the MND diagnosis.The condition affects the nerves that enable people to move, speak, breathe and swallow.The family ldquocautiously set a target of pound, but had smashed that before they even laced up their walking boots.Paul added: ldquoThe fact we hit pound, before we set off was just incredible.ldquoThe support we have had has been unbelievable lots of donations from strangers. We have had donations from Canada, Australia and France ndash it has been amazing.To support the good cause, go to munrosmnd

title: east-lothian-soil-expert-vows-offer-farmers-practical-support
story: Fergus Scougal has been appointed agronomist for East Lothian and the Borders by the company Agrovista.The -year-old completed a degree in agriculture at SRUCand also has on-farm experience via a range of practical roles.Following graduation, Fergus joined Agrii, where he built expertise in precision farming, as well as row crop agronomy.He now joins Agrovista as a fully qualied agronomist.The rugby and horse riding enthusiast, who lives at Ballencrieff, said: ldquoMy aim is to be a good agronomist with honest values by doing the best job that I can for the farmer.ldquoThis is how I want to do business ndash building long-lasting relationships with my customers. Irsquom looking forward to working for Agrovista as the company shares those values.ldquoThe team is farmer-focused and offers solutions that are practical, not unrealistic.ldquoIrsquom not from a farming background but agriculture has long been my interest, particularly the technical side of agronomy.

title: lending-library-scheme-created-lockdown-continue
story: A lending library offering people the chance to borrow books, games and jigsaws was established in May.The project has proven popular throughout the town, with people spending an increased amount of time indoors due to the pandemic.Pat Lemmon, who has been involved with the resilience group and is a member of the townrsquos community council, was keen to see the scheme remain in place.She said: ldquoThe lending library will continue as long as it is needed.ldquoWe have a core group of  people and these are people after the end of July who are still wary about coming out.ldquoWe have to respect they have a need and we can provide for that as long as we can.Each of the donated items goes through a thorough sanitising to ensure they are clean before they are loaned.

title: dunbar-rnlis-traditional-lifeboat-day-going-virtual
story: Dunbar Leboat Day is a firm fixture in the townrsquos calendar and a vital fundraiser for the lesaving crew.However, the coronavirus pandemic forced the cancellation of the event, which dates back to the s.Fortunately, Dunbarrsquos RNLI volunteers have stepped up to ensure that the popular event does not pass unmarked.A series of virtual activities are being planned from Saturday through to August , when the Leboat Queen will be crowned.Veronica Davies, Dunbar RNLI fundraising committee chair, hoped that the community would enjoy the on-screen activities and raise funds to help save lives at sea.She said: ldquoI know how special leboat day and the traditions behind it are to the community and thatrsquos why we couldnrsquot let a year go by without marking it in some way.ldquoWe have organised a lsquoVirtual Leboat Fetersquo, which we hope captures the publicrsquos imagination.ldquoDunbar has crowned a Leboat Queen every year since  and we wanted to continue that tradition.ldquoOur supporters have always amazed us with their response to our appeals in the past and, while we realise itrsquos a dficult time for many people, we hope they will amaze us once more.Two weeks of fun-filled activities will launch on Saturday, with painting, photography, baking, welly-decorating and picture caption competitions, as well as a pet show, a lsquopick a leboat stationrsquo game and quiz.All events will be organised online, with participants able to submit entries via their phones, tablets or computers.In addition, walkers and fun-runners are encouraged to join in the lsquoSkateraw Dashrsquo, a sponsored run or walk challenge for runners of all ages and capabilities that commemorates the days more than  years ago when the leboat crew, due to tide or bad weather, had to push the boat five miles from Dunbar to Skateraw to launch.The fete is Dunbar RNLIrsquos biggest annual fundraiser and last year the event raised a sizeable total of pound,.Traditionally, thousands turn out for the parade along High Street before heading to the harbour for an afternoon of music, fun activities, competitions and the Leboat Queenrsquos crowning ceremony.Mark Lees, Dunbar Leboat Station chairman, was glad to see the event going ahead, albeit in a dferent form.He said: ldquoAt first glance, not having leboat day feels a bit of a travesty, especially given all the tradition of the leboat in Dunbar and the way that we use this as not only a way of raising funds but our key interaction with our local community.ldquoIn these dficult times, we have to look past that and make sure that the safety of our community, our fundraisers and our crew must come first, so there really was no way we could run the fete in our traditional way that kept everyone absolutely safe.ldquoIt really is great, however, to be able to run the fete lsquovirtuallyrsquo, allowing our team to engage and interact with our community and maintain the tradition of leboat day, with a Leboat Queen, and ensure that the tradition of the station and community coming together can in some way be maintained.ldquoThat has been so important to all our crew and our fundraisers and I think so important to the ongoing history of our station.ldquoThere are loads of great, safe and socially distanced events to get involved in, so I would just encourage everyone to have a go at something to have some fun and support your leboat station.

title: community-resilience-groups-dunbar-haddington-musselburgh-north-berwick-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.As teams of volunteers get ready to step down, we look at five of the groups who have been giving up their own time to help out.DunbarDunbarMORE than , hot meals have been dished up to people throughout the Dunbar and East Linton ward in less than four months.The Dunbar and District Meals Service is entering its final week as lockdown restrictions are further eased.Over the course of the past  weeks during lockdown, the meals scheme has ensured that vulnerable and shielded iniduals in the ward have been provided with good-quality pre-prepared meals.George Robertson, who has been heavily involved with the resilience response in Dunbar, offered his praise to those involved in the scheme.He said: ldquoThe two organisers, Katy Pollock and Helen Harper, have done a terric job, and were able to recruit the services of three professional chefs from Thomas Franks Ltd, a catering company which normally provides a meals service for schools including Loretto and Belhaven Hill.ldquoMeals were prepared in the kitchens at Loretto School and then taken to the Bleachingfield Centre in Dunbar, where a team of local volunteers arranged distribution.ldquoThe service was very well received and recipients were grateful not just for the nourishing meals but also for the social contact with the volunteers that this provided.ldquoFunding came via Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership.ldquoNow that lockdown is easing and shielded iniduals can venture out, there is less of a need.ldquoAlso, our chefs will soonto their day jobs when the next school year begins.ldquoA very much reduced service will continue for about  families who still have a need.A short ceremony was arranged by Katy and Helen on Friday, with a buffet lunch and some small presentations to the three chefs and to the local volunteers who have delivered the meals.HaddingtonHaddingtonA MASSIVE thank you has been given to everyone who helped out throughout Haddington during lockdown.A team of volunteers helped the community resilience group organised by the townrsquos community council.Voluntary groups such as Haddington Rotary Club and Our Community Kitchen also helped ensure vulnerable members of the community received help.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the community council, has been at the helm of the community resilience effort.Volunteers have done everything from collecting shopping and prescriptions to dog walking and simply being someone for isolated people to talk to.Chris confirmed that the group would officially step down this weekend but schemes such as the lending library would continue.He said: ldquoI sent out an email last week to really thank the volunteers but it is not just them but the whole community that need to be thanked.ldquoWithout groups like the Rotary and Our Community Kitchen doing their bit, without people looking after their neighbours and family, it could have been a hell of a lot worse.ldquoWith the situation, it could have been a lot more of a dficult time. A few people have really struggled and we have helped where we could. It is gratying to know they have got the help that they need.ldquoIt is everybody in the town and the surrounding area that really needs to be thanked, not just volunteers and the resilience team.ldquoWe are a pretty large town and the number of calls and referrals has been relatively low for a , population.ldquoThere are other community councils that are a lot smaller than us but had a lot more to do. I put that down to everybody looking after everybody , neighbours looking after neighbours. If something goes to the point where someone is not getting help, that is where we get involved.ldquoIt has been absolutely wonderful seeing the community spirit over the past four months.Musselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghEAST Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant paid a visit to the Resilient Musselburgh base to see first-hand how the group has been supporting the community during lockdown.Michael Williams MBE recently met council staff and volunteers involved with the emergency response, which is co-ordinated at Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre.An army of  helpers ensured vulnerable people in the Musselburgh area, including Wallyford and Whitecraig, received food supplies and other deliveries such as prescriptions in the past four months.Last week, Resilient Musselburgh recognised the effort of local care homes with a surprise kindness gt of a food hamper and  boxes of chocolates.Iain Clark, chairman of Musselburgh Area Partnership and a Deputy Lieutenant, said: ldquoOur care homes have done a fantastic job of keeping residents safe and a well-deserved treat was a small way of saying thank you. These were delivered by some of our volunteers.The initiative has been led by the area partnership and Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council.Mr Williams praised the efforts of Resilient Musselburgh, saying: ldquoI was utterly humbled at what I saw and so incredibly impressed.ldquoThe coalition of community councillors, area partnership, volunteers, good neighbours, charities and businesses made le possible for all ages with wonderful food, school lunches, puzzles and books.He highlighted the emergency work which was replicated across East Lothian, adding that it ldquobrought out the absolute best in communities.He also paid tribute to the ldquofundamental work of East Lothian Foodbank.North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons LicenceNorth BerwickTHE North Berwick Resilience team stands down todayafter working since March to provide support to people in the town.Shielding is being lsquopausedrsquo by the Scottish Government from Saturday.The team has provided practical support, from collecting shopping and prescriptions to providing free face coverings and lsquokindness packsrsquo to people who are socially isolated and shielding.Sue Northrop, who holds responsibility for North Berwick Community Councilrsquos emergency plan, said thatpeople needed support after the end of the week they should contact North Berwick Community Centre on   or email nbccinfo@eastlothian.gov.ukShe added: ldquoResilience team members are now working with local groups and organisations to ensure that their hard work is used to build resilience in North Berwick.ldquoFor example, over  people have offered to volunteer in future emergencies and are interested in other ways of supporting the community.ldquoThe group is also keen to build on the success of the Street Links who have connected local communities during the crisis and the Digital Inclusion project, whichhas enabled people to communicate with their loved ones and seek help using computer tablets."The team will be preparing a report of what they have done and an outline for a new community emergency resilience plan.One of the initiatives set up by the team was using funds raised by North Berwick Community Council to pay for nearly  copies of the Courier to be given to people in isolation who could not access the internet to allow them to keep up to date with local news and what was happening.This week will be the last time the papers are distributed and Sue encouraged people who enjoyed reading the Courier and could afford to pay for it to contact local newsagentsthey wished to continue receiving the paper.ldquoThe Courier has played an important role in keeping people informed during this crisis and we were very happy to support it, she said.Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANSrsquo community resilience team will step down at the end of the month and community council chairman Brian Weddell has sent everyone who supported the team a thank you.Brian said: ldquoOn behalf of the Prestonpans resilience team, I wanted to take this opportunity to thank everyone who has helped our efforts over the past four months.ldquoI would particularly like to thank the hard core of volunteers who have given up their spare time or have utilised their time furloughed from work to help those people in Prestonpans who have been shielding or have been unable to get out of the house for essential supplies, especially during lockdown.ldquoThe pandemic wasnrsquot something East Lothian Council or any of the resilience groups had planned for but the way Panners pulled together was a credit to our local community.The team officially stands down today , when shielding ends, but the Pennypit Trust is continuing to deliver meals and shopping to elderly residents and vulnerable families.During lockdown, the Pennypit Pantry provided more than , meals and food parcels.Organisers plan to keep it running for those in need and are appealing for volunteers to help with deliveries.Anyone who can help is asked to contact Lorna on   or email lornabellany@gmailBrian said: ldquoDuring lockdown we were very lucky that Michelle and Calum Wilson from the Prestoungrange Gothenburg decided to help the community and, over the course of  weeks, they delivered , breakfast packs to homes in Prestonpans, Musselburgh, Port Seton, Tranent and Wallyford.ldquoAlso, Jane Russell and her team at East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes delivered over , boxes during the course of  weeks across East Lothian. You are still able to access East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes on  .ldquoWithout their work throughout the crisis, a lot of families would have struggled even more. East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes are always grateful for donations soyou are able to help, please get in touch with them.ldquoFinally, I would like to give a special shout out to the people who have kept the community councilrsquos resilience effort going since March .ldquoNicole Millar and Leanne Ward have administered the work of the team whilst still working full time, as well as fulfilling their own family commitments.ldquoAllan Sneddon stepped into the breach as acting SPoC, ably supported by his we Angela, and Janis Wilson and Kevin Dempsey, the Top and Bottom Pans team leaders.ldquoHowever, the most important work was done by the volunteers who have delivered leaflets, meals, shopping, prescriptions and carried out hours of dog walking.ldquoAll of them have done a tremendous job and made my task of writing a weekly local resilience report for the Courier that much easier, with such a positive story to tell.ldquoHopefully we will not have to go through this again but itrsquos good to know that we have so many community-minded people willing and able to help those less fortunate.ldquoIf you hear of anyone needing support after July , contact Emma Brown, PSG Connected Communities manager, on   or email prestonpansccrb@eastlothian.gov.ukOther resilience groups contact detailsAberladyIan Malcolm  Sam Robertson  www.facebook AberladyResilience-BoltonShena Jamieson   orshenajamieson@aolCockenzie  Port Seton Dirletonwww.dirletonresilience.orgEast SaltounBuffy Neilson   orbuffyneilson@yahooGfordJo Allen  chairgfordcc@gmailAdam White  adamjswhite@outlookWendy Ferguson  wendyferguson.wf@gmailThe Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell  anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukGullane gullanerteam@gmailHumbieMargo Hodge  LongniddrySheila Jamieson  Macmerry  Gladsmuir communityresilienceteam@gmailOrmiston OrmistonRCteam@hotmailTranent and Elphinstone tranentemergencyresponse@gmailWest SaltounDerek Smith  coruisk@gmail

title: east-lothian-council-offers-financial-aid-local-businesses
story: East Lothian Council has stepped in to do what it can to support businesses during the pandemic, with money coming from the Business Support Grants scheme, established by the Scottish Government.Councillor John McMillan, the local authorityrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to be able to help out.He said: ldquoThis has been perhaps the most challenging time for businesses that we have ever experienced, so I am really pleased that the council has been able to provide as much support as possible, and will continue to do so.ldquoA big lsquothank yoursquo to colleagues who worked really hard to process these grants as quickly as possible.A total of pound, has also been paid out in newly self-employed hardship grants and BB serviced accommodation hardship grants.The local authority also recently launched the lsquoStay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothianrsquo campaign, which encourages locals and visitors to fully explore the range of quality local businesses throughout East Lothian.Mr McMillan said: ldquoAs our high streets, hospitality industry and tourism-related businesses continue to re-open for business, our focus is moving more towards supporting them to attract more business and to do so safely.ldquoThe message in our Stay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothian campaign is very much that East Lothian is back open for business and leisure, and we are ready to welcome customers and visitors existing and new.ldquoThe council will continue to work with national bodies such as VisitScotland and Skills Development Scotland, and local businesses from every sector, to ensure there is support in place for all our industries to thrive and to ensure our workforce is as highly skilled as possible.ldquoI would urge all businesses in East Lothian to engage with us and to contact economic development for support with anything from starting-up, growing your business, moving or finding premises, skills training and funding.ldquoBy working together, we can do our best to ensure our valued, ied and innovative businesses survive and thrive after this pandemic.The Courierrsquos Love Local Business campaign urges people to back local businesses as they attempt to bounce back from the pandemic. Letrsquos rally together and show them the support they need to get through this tough time.

title: column-striking-right-balance
story: Remembering to take a mask can be frustrating when yoursquove left home without one.Irsquove started keeping them in dferent pockets and in the car or other accessible areas, much as I did with reading glasses.Using public transport is slightly more complicated, whether with booking or seating, but itrsquos manageable and staff are considerate and helpful.The challenges for businesses and agencies are even greater given scale and risk.Itrsquos not easy as options can be limited and alternatives few.But it must be done, as wersquore going to have to live this way for a while at least and some aspects may well become permanent.Thatrsquos certainly the situation over access to town centres.Things canrsquot be the same as before given the need for social distancing.However, engaging with communities and traders is essential.Letting people know and seeking input is courteous to say the least but also essential in finding a solution.Council staff have worked hard and are operating under immense pressure.But the diktat on parking and access by the Labour administration was wrong.That theyrsquove rolled back from original plans is to be welcomed, though it has to be accepted that there probably isnrsquot a perfect solution.But local voices need heard and green space is to be preserved.Parking cars on Elcho Green in North Berwick was absurd and almost a throwback to the worst aspects of s planning.There has to be a balance between access for vehicles and the safety of pedestrians.Parking sites will have to be found, hard though that may be, and vehicles will still need to be able to enter.Cycling and walking are being encouraged not just in reaction to Covid-, and everywhere, not just East Lothian.People have to be able to move safely as they shop and mingle, and town centres are for people, not just motor cars.Other communities have both managed it and been enhanced by it. Itrsquoll take time and a few iterations but we can get there.

title: column-steps-keep-river-esk-clean
story: They are taking prompt action to make this positive step towards cleaning the Esk from the mine water.The Coal Authority are working along with SEPA to put in a permanent mine water treatment scheme, which will take place within two to three years, but they are also working on an interim design which will be in place within a few months to treat mine water until the permanent solution is in place.This should help towards resolving the orange discolouration present in the river, which is as a result of iron from the mine workings, and these developments will promote a healthier river ecosystem.I am glad to see that they are keeping the community informed at this early stage, and that real progress is being made on this issue.It is important that you know what to expectyoursquore called by an NHS Contact Tracer in relation to the coronavirus.Contact tracers will firstly introduce themselves, state the reason for their call, and will always identy who they are calling by name.They will ask you to identy others who yoursquove been in close contact with and places yoursquove been  hours prior to the onset of symptoms up until the time yoursquove self-isolated.It is especially important to note that contact tracers will not ask anyone for information about bank accounts or medical records, and they will not try to sell you anything.Try to familiarise yourself with this practice, so that you do not fall victim to scams, and share this information with others.I know that many will be relieved to hear that those who have been shielding from coronavirus will no longer have to do so from August .I know that this announcement will be long-awaited for many, and I hope those who are affected look forward to seeing loved ones.

title: column-creating-home-county
story: The , residents worked locally, two-thirds living in towns.Half a century later, it had grown to , ndash extensive council house building bringing the urban share to  per cent.By the millennium, despite loss of mines, wire works and farm workers, we had grown to ,. Growth then accelerated and we grew to , by .Then East Lothian Councilcame out with its  Local Development Plan , which said the county ldquois forecast to grow by . per cent between  and  and ldquoconstraints mean the scope for further signicant expansion of existing settlements is limited.Actually, both statements are glib,not downright misleading. Consider the numbers for our six main towns and plug in the ,-plus new houses shown on the overview map on page  of the LDP, to be built by , giving the last column of the table .Some of the  increase is in villages unused to growth: Wallyford is doubling to , Blindwells will house , Gullane has reached its  per cent in as many months.That  per cent county growth represents twice our already record rate last century.Covid- will not slow this. House prices may waver in cities, but urban professionals have twigged they can telecommute from more pleasant environs than an Edinburgh tenement.Growth is not, in itself, evil. It can fund improvements. But ELC has serious form in failing to achieve this. Bad enough the only infrastructure provided in  years has been schools legally required and sports facilities mismanaged by place-men.Not one bypass or station not one major employer lured or business complex built.Worst of all, wilful ignorance of real town planning and what makes community was absent from the LDPrsquos  pages of flatulence.While millions were wasted on failed Dunbar and Musselburgh town centre lsquoregenerationrsquo, developers have made a killing creating only commuterville housing.We are becoming a Scottish lsquoHome Countyrsquo, like Surrey or Berkshire, where towns blot our countryside and people go where to work, shop or relax.

title: new-walking-route-set-open-papple
story: Papple Steading has worked with East Lothian Council to open the route.Run by the Mackintosh family, Papple Steading is a heritage, community and business development based in the listed farm buildings that were once part of the Whittingehame Estate.It has acquired woods where it plans to provide a path to connect ious sites of interest in the Papple, Garvald, Stoneypath and Morham area.The wood that will be made available, called Papana Wood, sits in a ravine known as Papana Glen by Papana Water.The walk will start at the steading, where there is parking and cycle racks available, and goes on to Stoneypath. It then carries on to Garvald and Gford.East Lothian Council and the Mackintosh family hope to enlist the help of voluntary groups to establish a proper path through the ancient woodland, which has been left completely undisturbed for decades.Nick Morgan, the access officer for the council, said: ldquoThis is an exciting opportunity for the arearsquos residents and visitors to interconnect a number of interesting and beautul sights.ldquoThe Papana walk will encourage people to find routes to explore Gford, Garvald, Stoneypath and the listed buildings at Papple Steading and then to climb Traprain, visit Hailes Castle and enjoy the attractions of East Linton.George Mackintosh of Papple Steading said: ldquoWe have all been through an emotionally moving and, for many, a sadly distressing experience with this pandemic.ldquoFor many, the countryside was a comfort and therapy.ldquoMany will want to continue their new recreation habits and many more will want to find peace and good health in walking around this lovely area in the foothills of the Lammermuir Hills.ldquoMy family are delighted to help make another small part of this countryside welcome to all visitors.Papple has also already begun to restore the th-century model farm that was once part of Whittingehame Estate.

title: bid-lodged-shop-cafe-next-car-dealership
